issues.text: Whether there was a criminal conspiracy under Section 120B IPC to manufacture bombs and strike terror?

anchor.surface_text: It would be appropriate to deal with the question of conspiracy. Section 120B of IPC is the provision which provides for punishment for criminal conspiracy. Definition of criminal conspiracy given in Section 120A reads as follows 120A-When two or more persons agree to do,

issues.text: Whether the confessional statements recorded under Section 164 CrPC were voluntary and admissible?

anchor.surface_text: That brings us to another angle i.e. acceptability of the confession. Section 24 of the Evidence Act interdicts a confession if it appears to the Court to be the result of any inducement, threat or promise in certain conditions.

issues.text: Whether confessions of co-accused can be used against other accused under Section 30 of the Evidence Act?

anchor.surface_text: The requirement of Section 30 of the Evidence Act is that before it is made to operate against the co accused the confession should be strictly established.

issues.text: Whether statements of conspirators fall within Section 10 of the Evidence Act, particularly post-arrest confessions?

anchor.surface_text: However, we find substance in the stand of learned counsel for accused-appellants that Section 10 of the Evidence Act which is an exception to the general rule while permitting the statement made by one conspirator to be admissible as against another conspirator restricts it to the statement made during the period when the agency subsisted.

holdings.text: Criminal conspiracy under Section 120B IPC is proved by circumstantial evidence, witness testimony, and confessions establishing agreement to manufacture bombs illegally.

anchor.surface_text: It would be appropriate to deal with the question of conspiracy. Section 120B of IPC is the provision which provides for punishment for criminal conspiracy. Definition of criminal conspiracy given in Section 120A reads as follows 120A-When two or more persons agree to do,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied definition from s120A IPC; proved by overt acts, circumstantial evidence, witness accounts, and confessions; no direct evidence needed.

holdings.text: Confessional statements under Section 164 CrPC are voluntary, true, and admissible as no inducement, threat, or promise found.

anchor.surface_text: That brings us to another angle i.e. acceptability of the confession. Section 24 of the Evidence Act interdicts a confession if it appears to the Court to be the result of any inducement, threat or promise in certain conditions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Magistrates followed procedure; retraction after two years is afterthought; double test of voluntariness and truthfulness satisfied.

holdings.text: Confession of co-accused under Section 30 Evidence Act can only lend assurance to other independent evidence and cannot be foundation of conviction.

anchor.surface_text: The requirement of Section 30 of the Evidence Act is that before it is made to operate against the co accused the confession should be strictly established.

holdings.reasoning_summary: First examined other evidence; confession used only for corroboration; followed Kashmira Singh principles.

holdings.text: Post-arrest confessional statements do not fall within Section 10 Evidence Act as agency of conspiracy ceases after arrest.

anchor.surface_text: However, we find substance in the stand of learned counsel for accused-appellants that Section 10 of the Evidence Act which is an exception to the general rule while permitting the statement made by one conspirator to be admissible as against another conspirator restricts it to the statement made during the period when the agency subsisted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Theory of agency limits to statements during subsistence of conspiracy; post-arrest statements inadmissible against co-conspirators.

holdings.text: Acts of manufacturing and possessing large quantities of bombs constitute terrorist acts under Sections 3(2)(i) and 3(3) TADA with intent to strike terror and affect communal harmony.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged with some amount of vehemence by the learned counsel for the appellants that no terrorist act was involved. While dealing with an accused tried under the TADA, certain special features of the said Statute need to be focused.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intent inferred from circumstances, quantity of explosives, and context; beyond ordinary law and order; preparation per se illegal.

holdings.text: No right of private defence available as no reasonable apprehension of imminent attack proven; bomb preparation illegal per se.

anchor.surface_text: Further question is when the right of private defence arises. It never commences before a reasonable apprehension arises in the mind of the accused.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Right arises only on apprehension of imminent harm; no evidence of impending attack; prior preparation not justified.

holdings.text: Accused guilty under Sections 3 and 5 Explosive Substances Act, or alternatively Section 4; possession and manufacture with unlawful intent established.

anchor.surface_text: On the question of applicability of Sections 3 and 4 of the Explosive Act and the true intent, we only need to refer to Corpus Juris Secundum...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intent from circumstances; conviction under higher or lesser offence sustainable; sentence unaffected.

holdings.text: Evidence of star witnesses PWs 40, 67, 68 reliable despite delay; natural presence and credible after scrutiny.

anchor.surface_text: First, we shall deal with the plea regarding acceptability of the evidence. It is to be seen as to what is the evidence of PWs 40, 67 and 68 and how they establish prosecution case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Delay explained by chaos post-explosion; consistent, natural witnesses; relatives affected.

holdings.text: Non-examination of certain witnesses like Nausad and Osman does not render prosecution case suspect; no adverse inference as material witnesses examined.

anchor.surface_text: Next comes the accused-appellants plea relating to non-examination of witnesses. Normally, the prosecutions duty is to examine all the eyewitnesses...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution not bound to examine all; quality over quantity; case established independently.

holdings.text: Acquittal under Sections 302/34 and 436/34 IPC justified; no interference.

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the appeal filed by the prosecution against the acquittal in respect of charges under Section 302/34 and Section 436/34 IPC...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution conceded; insufficient evidence for murder and mischief by fire.

holdings.text: Designated Courts should avoid unnecessary adjournments and deferred cross-examinations when witnesses are present, against spirit of Section 309 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Before parting with the case, we may point out that the Designated Court deferred the cross examination of the witnesses for a long time. That is a feature which is being noticed in many cases. Unnecessary adjournments give a scope

holdings.reasoning_summary: Causes hardship to witnesses; lacks expeditious trial spirit; deprecated practice.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals filed by the accused persons deserves to be dismissed, and we so direct. Coming to the appeal filed by the prosecution against the acquittal in respect of charges under Section 302/34 and Section 436/34 IPC, learned counsel for the prosecution fairly stated, and in our opinion rightly, that the acquittal is justified. Though, it was submitted by Mr. K.T.S.

outcome.relief_summary: All seven appeals (six by accused appellants challenging conviction and sentences, one by State challenging acquittal on Sections 302/34 and 436/34 IPC) dismissed. Convictions and life sentences under Section 120B IPC, Section 3(2)(i) TADA r/w 34 IPC, Section 3(3) TADA upheld. Convictions under Sections 3 and 5 Explosive Substances Act upheld. Acquittals under Sections 302/34 IPC and 436/34 IPC upheld.
directions: Trial courts must examine present witnesses without unnecessary adjournments; advocates must not seek adjournments for cross-examination without arrangements, to avoid hardship to witnesses

edges.explanation: a12 describes procedures followed, warnings given, magistrates confirmed voluntary, claiming satisfaction of CrPC Section 164 requirements for recording confessions.
a12's details on voluntary nature, warnings, magistrate confirmation, and procedures support the holding of voluntary and admissible statements.
a12 argues confessions voluntary with proper procedures, addressing the issue of voluntariness and admissibility under S164.
Argument that TADA s15 confessions deserve greater acceptability supports the holding that 164 CrPC confessions are voluntary and admissible.
Argument on greater acceptability of TADA s15 confessions addresses the issue of voluntariness and admissibility of 164 CrPC confessional statements.
Argument on Section 10 limitation to during subsistence and post-arrest inapplicability addresses the issue of Section 10 applicability to post-arrest confessions.
a16 asserts conviction sustainable under s3 or s4 with possession and purpose to bombs, responding to a9's claim of no s3 application but s4 conviction.
Argument establishes possession of explosives, purpose to manufacture bombs, and constructive liability, supporting holding's proof of agreement to manufacture bombs illegally under 120B.
Argument on possession, purpose to manufacture bombs addresses the issue of criminal conspiracy under 120B to manufacture bombs and strike terror.

Argument proving conspiracy by circumstantial evidence, testimony, and confessions grounds the holding that conspiracy under 120B is proved.
Argument on proof of criminal conspiracy by evidence addresses the issue of whether there was conspiracy under Section 120B to manufacture bombs.
